text:
PROFESSOR: They have
now been working

on the first project, the
quarry project, for two weeks.

And during that time,
there was a pin up.

Then we asked them
to do a first design

at a very small scale, which
you see here, of one project,

of this outside
classroom shelter out
of the rain and the sun.

You see the scale, the
person to the total project.

There was a pin up to
criticize that project.

And then we asked
them to blow it up

in scale to quarter
scale, that you see here,

and more detail and
revise, at the same time,

based on the criticism
that they received.

And so in addition to
the model that you see,

we also asked them to make
drawings of sections and plans
and details of their project.
This is a typical one.

Now at this point
we had a review,

where I asked people from
offices around Boston,

as well as other faculty,
to come and criticize them.

So this was their
very first review

of exposing their
work to other people.

And what you're about to
see is a typical review

of what I call a one on one
or small quiet discussions

between one or two
faculty and one student.

It's my belief that it's more
educational if you can not

have the old style jury system,
which was a number of faculty

listening to the student
presenting and then

criticizing, which I don't
think was too educational.

This way is more quiet,
but I think it's more--

its fact that it's more informal
makes it more educational.

I think students
get more out of it.

So you're about to see a typical
review of what I call one

on ones, although you
may find two faculty,
or two people with one student.

STUDENT: It's basically
my passion looks like
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

STUDENT: The entrance where
you come from the trail

is sort of about
here, so that we--
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

STUDENT: And so I
didn't really feel

like I was capable of
duplicating anything
that could compete with that.

So I sort of took the
approach of, well,

I'm going to do something
that's obviously not

imitating but still drawing
on some of the principles--
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

STUDENT: Because I
didn't really want

to feel like I was
competing, like

you're bringing in people to
this beautiful place and then
[INAUDIBLE].

No matter how interesting
what you're saying is,

somebody is going
to find something

more interesting to
look at somewhere else.
So I kept that [INAUDIBLE].
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

STUDENT: I really like the
feeling of being on a dock,
like walking out onto a dock.

Being very conscious that
I'm elevated above the water.
I can feel the water if need be.

I wasn't sure if
I wanted to make

all these concrete
blocks or [INAUDIBLE]
coming up in these shapes.

[INAUDIBLE] and I really
wanted to have as much--
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

PROFESSOR: Yeah,
I think you always

experience that from far away
looking at the project where

it has a very
definite right now,

a very definite
vertical element to it.
For instance, we're saying--
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

PROFESSOR: When I
looked at this project,

before I had any idea
of scale or where

I saw your roof or
anything and I looked away

I remember thinking, where those
roofs or were those platforms?

And I think something very
interesting about this
[INAUDIBLE].

You never quite know
if something is a step

or it's a seat or
it's a ledge or it's
going to give you shade.

And I think that's
something that

can be very exciting about
[INAUDIBLE] to me anyway

looking at it, it
already almost has that.

It could be very exciting
about this that could also

help you to touch
[INAUDIBLE] in some places

if you didn't just have one
access because otherwise, it
wouldn't work.
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

PROFESSOR: You could almost
set up a system where--

depending on how
you explore this,

you could use something
as a roof or as a platform

or as something that goes on top
of you depending on where you
[INAUDIBLE].

And you still could have some
[INAUDIBLE] things around,
but I think that--

and then also, this integration
with this a little bit
stops [INAUDIBLE].
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

PROFESSOR: I think it does make
it more of a stand along thing.

So I would be very excited to
see more of this sort of thing
happening.

[INAUDIBLE] You sort
of said it already

because you were talking about
the architectural components

in the landscape, so use them
as architectural components.
Use something as base.

STUDENT: I had a platform that
sort of sat right here that

would have acted as a roof for
this [INAUDIBLE] right here.
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

STUDENT: But I had initially
wanted that duality of you

can be on top and you can be
underneath at the same time.
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

PROFESSOR: You land at
almost the water level.

You sit down so that you're
adjacent to the water.
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

STUDENT: Basically,
my idea of [INAUDIBLE]
that had a sense of privacy.

I guess the program [INAUDIBLE]
wanted a place for the class

to be in as well as places
for individuals to alone,

and I wanted to go to places
that have [INAUDIBLE]..

I didn't want to make something
that was like enclosed,

but I wanted a
sense of enclosure

for [INAUDIBLE] and
shelter purposes.

I guess my whole
project is pretty much
based on [INAUDIBLE].

This summer, I was in China
for two and a half months,

and we went to a lot
of bamboo forests.

And those had a sense of
serenity inside of them,
and so that's what [INAUDIBLE].

This is our initial
collage of ideas.

One of the other things I
noticed about the [INAUDIBLE]

was a sense of how there wasn't
really a human scale to it.
[INAUDIBLE]
Yeah.

In the sense that I had
some preliminary time

to judge the distances and
dimensions [INAUDIBLE]..

I wanted to have something
that was bold and outstanding

like the quarry itself,
but it was natural in form

without necessarily
imitating [INAUDIBLE]..

My initial idea is in
the eight inch models.
I knew I wanted to have that.

Another idea was I
wanted to incorporate

into my design was
the idea of the curve

and a simple gesture can serve
the dual purpose of providing
that space of interaction--
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

STUDENT: And then, all along
here, along the outer rings,

I brought a lot of different
places for people to have
[INAUDIBLE].
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

STUDENT: I also wanted
to include [INAUDIBLE]
to allow light to come in.

So I didn't have
it solid purposely

so that the inside [INAUDIBLE]
to the bottom of this.
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

PROFESSOR 2: I think you're
right in noting that this

wouldn't necessarily be an
all weather place [INAUDIBLE]

in the interstitial spaces,
you might not want to be there,
so you have to [INAUDIBLE].

And I would say, well, if
it's just frosted glass, well,
what is it doing?

It'll diffuse the
light a little bit,

but it's not the [INAUDIBLE]
really hot days such as we
had earlier this summer.
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

PROFESSOR 2: Would allow you to
take the idea that you brought

back from China,
but maybe make it

a little more in keeping with
what the program would be here.

Start from the inspiration
of what you saw there,
but it is [INAUDIBLE].

It's a different sort
of place than the quarry
and for a different experience.
It's different.

You tend to walk
through or something.

You're not going to
have a class here

or in the studio
or some things that
are requirements for shelters.

STUDENT 2: It's very
similar, actually,

to some of these plants
growing up out of the rock.

You have these columns
seemingly coming out
of the cracks in the rock.

And like Angela said, I
think breaking it up a bit
would be beneficial.

Maybe there's different
types of material
that are above your head.

I know when you walk
into a grove of bamboo,

it's actually
quite dark in there

because of the
complexity of the leaves

and the density the
leaves above your head.

So if you broke this
up a bit on the side

and created different
intensities of columns,

and maybe there's two or three
types of roofing material.

Or you might create
areas that are

a bit darker or some lighter,
some maybe in the middle
are wide open.

Another way it could be that you
change the experience of moving

up from up high on the
quarry down to the quarry

so you're passing through
this kind of forest

and then finally you're
back out in the opening.

So I think adding that kind of
diversity to the architecture
would be beneficial.
